name: 閱讀專題討論
goals: This course aims at helping students become familiar with reading theories, research, and practices in L1 and L2.
syllabus:
**Week   Content**    

**Part I. Reading Processes and Reading Models**

(1).    **3/5** Course overview

(2).       **3/12**

              1. A Historical Perspective on Reading Research and Practice. By P. Alexander and E Fox. In _Theoretical models and processes of reading_, (5th edition), pp. 33-68, 2004, IRA

2\. Children’s Language and World: Initial Encounters with Print. By J Harste, C Baker, V Woodward, in _Theoretical models and Processes of reading_, (4th edition), pp. 48-69, 1994, IRA

(3).       **3/19**

              1. To Err Is Human: Learning about Language Processes by Analyzing Miscues. Y Goodman and K Goodman, in _Theoretical models and processes of reading_, (5th edition), pp. 620-639, 2004, IRA

2\. Toward a Theory of Automatic Information Processing in Reading, Revisited, S.

J. Samuels, in _Theoretical models and processes of reading,_ (5th edition), pp.     

1127-1148, 2004, IRA

3\. Toward an Interactive Model of Reading, D. Rumelhart, in _Theoretical models and processes of reading_, (5th edition), pp. 1149-1179, 2004, IRA

(4).        **3/26**

                       1. The Transactional Theory of Reading and Writing, L Rosenblatt, in

_Theoretical models and processes of reading_, (5th edition), pp. 1363-1398, 2004, IRA

            2. A Theory of Reading: From Eye Fixations to Comprehension. By M.A Just and P. Carpenter. in _Theoretical models and processes of reading_, (5th edition), pp. 1182-1218, 2004, IRA

(5).           **4/2**  Holiday

(6).           **4/9**

                      1. Reading as a Meaning-construction Process: The Reader, the Texts and the Teacher, By R. Ruddell and N. Unrau. In _Theoretical models and processes of reading_, (5th edition), pp. 1462-1521, 2004, IRA

            2.Vocabulary Knowledge and Comprehension: A Comprehension-Process View of Complex Literacy Relationships, M. Ruddell, in _Theoretical models and processes of reading_, (4th edition), pp. 414-447, 1994, IRA

        3. Role of the Reader’s Schema in Comprehension, Learning and Memory, R. Anderson, in _Theoretical models and processes of reading_, (5th edition), pp. 594-606, 2004, IRA

(7).         **4/16**

                      1. Young Children’s Regulatory Talk: Evidence of Emerging Metacognitive Control over Literacy Products, B. Cox, in _Theoretical models and processes of reading_, (4th edition), pp. 733-756, 1994, IRA

2\. Becoming A Strategic Reader, S. Paris, M. Lipson, K. Wixson, in _Theoretical models and processes of reading_, (4th edition), pp. 788-810, 1994, IRA

**Part II. Reading in a Second Language**

(8).      **4/23**  Midterm Project due

1\. Issues in Second Language Reading: Implicaitons for Acquisition and Instruction. Hossein N (2011). Reading Research Quarterly 46(2): 173-184.

2\. Reading as a Social Interactive Process: The Impact of Shadow-reading in L2 Classroom. Commander & de Guerrero (2013). Reading in a Foreign Language 25 (2):170-191.

3.. Fine Brush and Freehand: The Vocabulary-Learning Art of Two Successful Chinese EFL Learners. By Peter Yongqi Gu. _TESOL Quarterly_, 37:73-104  

(9).     **4/30**

1\. Cultural Familiarity in Inferential and Literal Comprehension in L2

Reading. Alptekin, C. (2006). _System_, 34: 494-508.

         2. Pre-reading Materials from Subject Matter. Texts---Learner choices and the Underlying Learner Characteristics. Huang, SC, Cheng, Y.S., and Chern, C.L. (2006). Journal of English for Academic Purposes, 5: 193-206.

3\. Gender difference and EFL reading comprehension: Revisiting topic interest and test performance. (2014). _System_, 42: 70-80

(10).      **5/7**

**1\.** ESP Reading Literacy and Reader Identity: A Narrative Inquiry Into a Learner in Taiwan Beryl C Lee and C.L. Chern  (2011) _Journal of Language, Identity, and Education_, 10: 346–360.

2\. L2 learners’ conceptions of academic reading and themselves as academic readers. (2014). _System_, 81-92.

3\. A Dynamic Metacognitive Systems Account of Chinese University Students’ Knowledge about EFL Reading. Zhang, L. (2010). TESOL Quarterly, 44(2):320-352

(11).  **5/14**

1\. Technologies for Teaching and Learning L2 Reading. Liaw and English (2017). The Handbook of Technology and Second language Teaching and Learning. (Eds., Chapelle and Sauro), John Wiley and Sons, Inc. 

2\. Enhancing L2 Digital Reading for EFL Learners. Liu, Y.T. (2015). _English Teaching and Learning,_ 39(2), 33-64

 (12). **5/21**

1\. EFL Learners’ Use of Online Reading Strategies and comprehension of text. Huang, H., Chern, C., Lin, C. (2006). _Computers and Education_.52:13-26.

          2. Online Reading Strategies at Work: What Teachers Think and What Students

Do. Huang, H.C. (2013). ReCALL, 25(3):340-358.

 (13). **5/28**

1\. Effects of interactive versus simultaneous display of multimedia glosses on L2 reading comprehension and incidental vocabulary learning. _Computer Assisted Language Learning_ (2014), 27: 1-25.

2\. Learning English with Electronic Textbooks on Tablet PCs. Lin C.C. (2017). Interactive learning Environment, 25:8, 1035-1047.

(14).    **6/4**

1\. Evaluating L2 Readers’ Previewing Strategies Using Eye Tracking. Prichard,

C. and Atkins, A. (2016). The Reading Matrix: An International Online Journal. 16(2): 110-130.

2\. Meaningfulness in the Eye of the Reader: Eye-tracking Insights of L2 Learners Reading e-Books and their Pedagogical Implications. Liu, T; Liu, Y.T., Chen, D. (2019). Interactive Learning Environments, 27(2): 181-199.

3\. The cognitive processing of candidates during reading tests: Evidence from eye-tracking. Bax, S. (2013). _Language Testing_, 30: 441-465.

(15).    **6/11** 

   1. Why don’t they do it? A study on the implementation of extensive reading in Taiwan. Huang, Y.C. (2015). Cogent Education 2:1.

   2. Explicit reading strategy instruction or daily use of strategies? Studying the teaching of reading comprehension through naturalistic classroom observation in English L2. Brevik, L.M. (2019). Reading and Writing 32:2281-2310

(16).    **6/18**  Final presentation

(17).    **/25**   Holiday

(18).    **7/2**   Final project due
